text: the Zimbabwean leader Robert Mugabe has
been seen in public for the first time
since the military takeover on Wednesday
he's attended a university graduation
ceremony in the capital Harare earlier
the military said talks with Mr Mugabe
were continuing and there'd been
significant progress in the operation
targeting what it called the criminals
surrounding him Ben Brown reports from
Zimbabwe he was supposed to be under
house arrest but today it looked like
business as usual for Robert Mugabe
awarding degrees to university graduates
in Harare and even walking down a red
carpet so after this week's dramatic
military takeover here is he still
president or not out on the streets no
one seems quite sure right across in Bob
we millions of people are waiting and
watching to see what happens next in
this crisis and whether the rule of
Robert Mugabe after 37 years is finally
coming to an end after decades of
political oppression an economic
disaster Zimbabweans are hungry for
change almost any kind of change we
don't grab anymore please everyone go to
the Swiss and move around now unlike
some Gabby and at this time we are going
to tell him we told one Jim he must go
the country's been going backwards we
can't reinvent the wheel the wheels
already been invented
seems to happen in this country tired of
baking food for my baby to put on the
table no we say no to that we need
better things here to happen in this
country the Zimbabwe Defense Forces the
ZDF say significant progress has been
made in their operation Robert Mugabe
has been negotiating with the head of
the army here general Constantino
chaweng gah but it still isn't clear
whether Mr Mugabe is trying to cling to
power or to negotiate a dignified exit
in which he would step down in return
for guarantees about his safety and that
of his family if that happened one
scenario could be a transitional
government run by zanu-pf but including
members of the opposition Zimbabwe once
again is at a crossroads Ben Brown BBC
News Zimbabwe well our senior Africa
correspondent and xoi is in Zimbabwe and
she joins us now and what do you know
about the state of the negotiations well
they have been going on it is a delicate
and difficult process given that we
understand mr. Mugabe is hesitant to
step down at this point in time they
would much rather wait until December
when he steps down as the leader of the
ruling Zanu PF party and then next year
when the planned elections are scheduled
to take place in which then he would not
defend his seat however the end looks
very imminent there are already talks
within his ruling party's on opf for
possible vote on Sunday to decide
whether he remains and if that passes
then they may vote to impeach him
however we understand the offer is if he
chooses to step down then there would be
no implications for him and his wife how
likely is that though I wonder he's
proved very resilient and defiant in the
past hasn't he that's right he's been
very resilient he's gone through
disputed elections and and still
continued to real to rule this country
he has withstood the challenge from the
from the West for instance through the
economic son
he has withstood so much but there are
three critical institutions or
organizations in this country that are
speaking out one is his party zanu-pf
the other one is the military which has
made it very clear that they need to
change the way things around in this
country and the other one is the more
veterans the war veterans have spoken
out today and they have said that um
they have given him an ultimatum to step
down immediately and here they have
called for a rally tomorrow here in
Zimbabwe and is's and Bob Wales to join
them to put pressure on Mr Mugabe to
step down and in the meantime who is
actually running the country at the
moment the military appears in control
and they appear to be managing things
including allowing him to attend the
graduation ceremony today
however they say that he remains
president and we interpret this to mean
that they wanted to show him respect he
is still respected as an independence
icon in Zimbabwe and so they wouldn't
want to humiliate him even though he has
already been humiliated by being put and
house arrest they would want a dignified
exit for him however if he chooses to
remain defiant they may be forced to use
to exert more pressure on him including
impeaching him thanks Anne and soy or
senior Africa correspondent in Zimbabwe
